 There are a few possibilities.
 
 For example, it could be that no absolute right or wrong exist. But to positively claim this, is like being a gnostic atheist - it involves claiming the absolute non-existence of something perhaps undetectable. It's all very well and good to say "Undetectable Pink Unicorns certainly don't exist in my basement", but its a claim that can't really ever be proved.
 
 It could be for example, that an absolute right and wrong exist, but that we have no way of knowing them. God could have generated an objective right and wrong set and be sitting back, from behind the curtains. But we can't know.
 
 The agnostic position is that we can't know whether they exist or don't, because of epistemological problems we encounter. Given an absence of any other proof for them, this would seem to be the most reasonable position - "I don't believe in an objective morality because I have not seen any proof of its existence, however I do not positively claim it does not exist."
 
 The questioned posed therefore, somewhat miss the mark.
 
 
1. From where does a person come to know what is objectively right or wrong?
 2. What method can we use to obtain this objective information?
 3. How do we determine if the information received from this source, is true or false?
 

 
 Even if someone has no way of knowing, (epistemological problems), this does not show the objective does not exist. Again we fall back to the agnostic position - it's possible we simply cannot know. In short, the fact we have no way of knowing if there is life on other planets, or if God exists, in no way demonstrates that the answers to these questions are not objective - as such, absence of knowledge poses no logical problem for moral absolutism, though it does make it very much irrelevant to our everyday lives. If, that is, this absolute system is unknowable. And even if we lacked knowledge now, that would not demonstrate to us that something was inherently unknowable.
 
 As Eddie pointed out however, there is a degree of circularity in the assertion of moral relativism. Even if it were true, why should anyone believe it? Why shouldn't someone simply believe there exist an absolute set? Whatever answer you provide undermines the position. To say, "You should believe it, because it is true" rests on the idea that truth is a universal or absolute good. Otherwise, why isn't something's truth just as good a reason for not believing in it? Why not say, "Because moral relativism is true, we should all believe in moral absolutism."?
 
 Indeed, it may be that moral absolutism, even if not actually true, is a more profitable system to live by. Christianity has survived for thousands of years, and it preaches moral absolutism. Even if moral relativism is true, why should anyone believe it - unless Truth is ultimately, and absolutely, the right system to live by?
 
 So essentially, you can pick at absolutism, but the holes dug so far aren't really holes at all. Even if it is impossible to determine what the objective system is, that does not imply it does not exist. At best we can say there is no reason we should believe in it - but if moral relativism is true, there is no such thing as an "objectively" good reason to believe in anything anyway.
 
 By the moral relativist's own admission, there is no more reason we should believe in moral relativism than moral absolutism.
 
 So it appears the debate is insoluble - if we cannot identify a set of ethics, objectively, and somehow determine them in such a way that they are undeniably and irreffutably true, there is no real reason we should believe in either system any more than the other, if we believe in either of them at all.
 
 Kant however, and those who have drawn from him, raise the possibility of a way out of this bind. I was inspired by Mach actually, who I had seen argue that thought neccessarily implied language. Descartes wrote; Cogito, Ergo Sum. Perhaps the important lesson we should draw from Descartes is not that we exist, but that we think. And if thought, as Mach argues, implies language - language implies certain rules. There can be no language in which X is not X, or in which a square is round. Certainly you could have a language in which the word "square" meant "round thing", but you cannot have a language in which a 4 cornered shape with equal length sides is perfectly round. Bound up in this language, which is implied in thought, are the rules, for example of mathematics. If we were to travel to the other side of the galaxy, and discover an alien race who had independently, with minds vastly dissimilar to ours, discovered the science of numbers, the rules of their maths would be, at the deepest level, the same as ours. (Even if they used Base 8 or 13 instead of 10, for example).
 
 And, some would argue, ethical rules are bound up in this language too, they are implied in the very nature of thinking. By this token they would apply to all conscious minds, and by their very nature be egalitarian, applying to all people (and indeed, alien life forms with a reasonably high level of intelligence). They would satisfy for example, the requirements of Kant's Categorical Imperative. The conclusions drawn are remarkably cohesive with traditional ethical principles - Equal rights for all, the golden rule, eye for an eye, the sanctity of life, "that which is consented to is no harm", a great deal of coherence with the "natural law" theories that blossomed during the enlightenment, and so on, all appear closely related to the deductions these apriori theorists claim are logical consequences of the fact that we are thinking beings.
 
 Now I am personally agnostic on the issue. I have not studied such arguments in depth enough to declare them correct. But at least they may offer one thing which the moral relativist's position does not - if they are correct, we will actually have a good reason to believe in them.

The 'relative' aspect of morality in this view lies in our ability simultaneously to apply different moral standards to different groups, or to re-define group membership over time and adjust our attitudes and behaviour to others accordingly.

Moral relativism is the position that moral propositions do not reflect absolute or universal truths. It not only holds that ethical judgments emerge from social customs and personal preferences, but also that there is no single standard by which to assess an ethical proposition's truth. Many relativists see moral values as applicable only within certain cultural boundaries. Some would even suggest that one person's ethical judgments or acts cannot be judged by another, though most relativists propound a more limited version of the theory.
 
 Some moral relativists - for example, Jean-Paul Sartre (1905-1980) - hold that a personal and subjective moral core lies at the foundation of our moral acts. They believe that public morality is a reflection of social convention, and that only personal, subjective morality is truly authentic.
 
 Moral relativism is not the same as moral pluralism, which acknowledges the co-existence of opposing ideas and practices, but does not suggest that they are equally valid. Moral relativism, in contrast, contends that opposing moral positions have no truth value, and that there is no preferred standard of reference by which to judge them.
